awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transition to Turbulence and Mixing for Rayleigh Taylor Instability with Acceleration Reversal
awd_abstract_narration:
1453056
Banerjee

The focus of this proposal is to use both computational and experimental components to elucidate mixing in variable density turbulence (i.e., when two fluids of different density mix because of turbulence). The bulk of prior research in this area has focused on the easier case of transport of mass without effects on the flow field, and on canonical flows (e.g., channel flows, jet flows, boundary layers). The proposed research aims to overcome the difficulties associated with experimental studies of non-canonical flows (these flows are the ones commonly found in industry and in nature), and to measure turbulence quantities in unprecedented details in new settings. Such work can open up developments in other areas of fluid dynamics, including multiphase flow, heat transfer and combustion and shock-driven flows. The proposed educational activities include the involvement of a local community college in the PI's research, the development of an educational video series that would be available through iTunes, and the inclusion of 8th to 12th graders in summer camps for research. 

The goal of the proposed research is to investigate the Rayleigh-Taylor instability in variable density flows using both experiments and simulations. This instability occurs when two fluids of different density are in contact, and the denser fluid is accelerated by the lighter fluid. The PI has built a rather unique experimental facility that would enable him to complete the experimental part of the proposed work. It is a device that allows the control of acceleration and deceleration of the fluid in a rotating system. The experimental system even allows the switch from acceleration to deceleration and then further reversals of acceleration. The PI proposes the use of planar laser-induced fluorescence, PLIF, and stereo-Particle Image Velocimetry to obtain high order statistics for the flow and scalar fields. In order to complement the experiments with state-of-the-art simulations, the PI has established a collaboration with LANL to conduct direct numerical simulations (DNS) of the flow.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Turbulence research over the last century has concentrated on passive-scalar mixing encompassing several canonical flows such as jets, free shear layers, and boundary layers. Far less attention has been given to the variable density turbulent flows, likely due to difficulties associated with developing experimental facilities and the application of high-fidelity diagnostics to such experiments. The project focused on the need to understand the physics associated with turbulent acceleration-driven Rayleigh Taylor Instability (RTI) that results in mixing multiple fluids/materials. Mixing of mass, momentum, and energy in complex flows under such extreme conditions has widespread applications in inertial confinement fusion, chemical reactors, heat exchangers, supernova explosions, volcanic island formation, and climate dynamics. 

Computational studies were conducted for RTI undergoing acceleration reversal(s) at various Atwood and Reynolds numbers. Synergistic Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS) were performed with partners at Los Alamos National Laboratory to provide a higher-order statistical description and a detailed understanding of the flow field. For the DNS, a triply periodic domain that mimics the core of the RTI mixing layer was chosen. Different flow regimes have been identified: a regime of initial growth dominated by diffusion, followed by explosive growth similar to RTI mixing with localized stirring and strong buoyancy forces. The turbulence subsequently slows down such that the flow is in saturated growth. Finally, the flow encounters a period of fast decay where buoyancy forces are relatively strong, followed by gradual (late) decay where the layer is mostly molecularly mixed as buoyancy forces continue to weaken. In addition, the project also led to the development of the Rotating Wheel RTI Experiment, which studies two-fluid mixing to mimic inertial confinement fusion. The data generated within the project is already being used to improve and calibrate turbulence models and to examine various multi-resolution representation methods for data compression and new strategies for codes in the broader turbulence community.

On the educational side, the award has led to the development of a graduate course in Mechanical Engineering and Mechanics and initiated an educational video series of elementary concepts in fluid mechanics. In addition, the project has led to workforce training and has led to support for three Ph.D. students, four M.S. students, and two undergraduate students. Student recruitment provided research experiences to women and minority undergraduate students to enhance retention in STEM disciplines. The research team also partnered with  Lehigh University's outreach office to provide hands-on experiences to economically disadvantaged, at-risk 8th-12th-grade students in the Students That Are Ready program.


Last Modified: 04/05/2022
Modified by: Arindam Banerjee
